natural problem:
A scanning code consists of a $7 \times 7$ grid of squares, with some of its squares colored black and the rest colored white. There must be at least one square of each color in this grid of $49$ squares. A scanning code is called $\textit{symmetric}$ if its look does not change when the entire square is rotated by a multiple of $90 ^{\circ}$ counterclockwise around its center, nor when it is reflected across a line joining opposite corners or a line joining midpoints of opposite sides. What is the total number of possible symmetric scanning codes?
$\textbf{(A)} \text{ 510} \qquad \textbf{(B)} \text{ 1022} \qquad \textbf{(C)} \text{ 8190} \qquad \textbf{(D)} \text{ 8192} \qquad \textbf{(E)} \text{ 65,534}$
natural solution: Draw a $7 \times 7$ square. $\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline K & J & H & G & H & J & K \\ \hline J & F & E & D & E & F & J \\ \hline H & E & C & B & C & E & H \\ \hline G & D & B & A & B & D & G \\ \hline H & E & C & B & C & E & H \\ \hline J & F & E & D & E & F & J \\ \hline K & J & H & G & H & J & K \\ \hline \end{tabular}$

Start from the center and label all protruding cells symmetrically. (Note that "I" is left out of this labelling, so there are only 10 labels, not 11, as ending in K would suggest!) More specifically, since there are $4$ given lines of symmetry ($2$ diagonals, $1$ vertical, $1$ horizontal) and they split the plot into $8$ equivalent sections, we can take just one-eighth and study it in particular.
Each of these sections has $10$ distinct sub-squares, whether partially or in full.
So since each can be colored either white or black, we choose $2^{10}=1024$ but then subtract the $2$ cases where all are white or all are black. That leaves us with $\boxed{1022}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes symmetric_scanning_codes :: nat
assumes h0 : "symmetric_scanning_codes = (\<Sum> i | 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 5. 2 powr (i * i))"
shows  "symmetric_scanning_codes = 1022"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A scanning code consists of a $7 \times 7$ grid of squares, with some of its squares colored black and the rest colored white. There must be at least one square of each color in this grid of $49$ squares. A scanning code is called $\textit{symmetric}$ if its look does not change when the entire square is rotated by a multiple of $90 ^{\circ}$ counterclockwise around its center, nor when it is reflected across a line joining opposite corners or a line joining midpoints of opposite sides. What is the total number of possible symmetric scanning codes?
$\textbf{(A)} \text{ 510} \qquad \textbf{(B)} \text{ 1022} \qquad \textbf{(C)} \text{ 8190} \qquad \textbf{(D)} \text{ 8192} \qquad \textbf{(E)} \text{ 65,534}$
 The final Answer is 1022
 ### Proof
 Draw a $7 \times 7$ square. $\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline K & J & H & G & H & J & K \\ \hline J & F & E & D & E & F & J \\ \hline H & E & C & B & C & E & H \\ \hline G & D & B & A & B & D & G \\ \hline H & E & C & B & C & E & H \\ \hline J & F & E & D & E & F & J \\ \hline K & J & H & G & H & J & K \\ \hline \end{tabular}$
 Start from the center and label all protruding cells symmetrically. (Note that "I" is left out of this labelling, so there are only 10 labels, not 11, as ending in K would suggest!) More specifically, since there are $4$ given lines of symmetry ($2$ diagonals, $1$ vertical, $1$ horizontal) and they split the plot into $8$ equivalent sections, we can take just one-eighth and study it in particular.
 Each of these sections has $10$ distinct sub-squares, whether partially or in full.
 So since each can be colored either white or black, we choose $2^{10}=1024$ but then subtract the $2$ cases where all are white or all are black. That leaves us with $\boxed{1022}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes symmetric_scanning_codes :: nat
assumes h0 : "symmetric_scanning_codes = (\<Sum> i | 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 5. 2 powr (i * i))"
shows  "symmetric_scanning_codes = 1022"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the sum of the first five symmetric scanning codes, where each code is calculated as $2^{i^2}$ for $1 \leq i \leq 5$. The final answer is 1022.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes symmetric_codes :: nat
assumes h0 : "symmetric_codes = (card {C :: (bool set) ^ (nat * nat). \<exists> f. bij f \<and> (\<forall> i j. i < 7 \<and> j < 7 \<longrightarrow> 
((f (i, j) = f (j, i)) \<and> (f (i, j) = f (6 - i, j)) \<and> (f (i, j) = f (i, 6 - j)) \<and> (f (i, j) = f (6 - i, 6 - j))
\<and> (f (i, j) = f (6 - j, i)) \<and> (f (i, j) = f (j, 6 - i)) \<and> (f (i, j) = f (6 - j, 6 - i)))})}"
shows  "symmetric_codes = 1022"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A scanning code consists of a $7 \times 7$ grid of squares, with some of its squares colored black and the rest colored white. There must be at least one square of each color in this grid of $49$ squares. A scanning code is called $\textit{symmetric}$ if its look does not change when the entire square is rotated by a multiple of $90 ^{\circ}$ counterclockwise around its center, nor when it is reflected across a line joining opposite corners or a line joining midpoints of opposite sides. What is the total number of possible symmetric scanning codes?
$\textbf{(A)} \text{ 510} \qquad \textbf{(B)} \text{ 1022} \qquad \textbf{(C)} \text{ 8190} \qquad \textbf{(D)} \text{ 8192} \qquad \textbf{(E)} \text{ 65,534}$
 The final Answer is 1022
 ### Proof
 Draw a $7 \times 7$ square. $\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline K & J & H & G & H & J & K \\ \hline J & F & E & D & E & F & J \\ \hline H & E & C & B & C & E & H \\ \hline G & D & B & A & B & D & G \\ \hline H & E & C & B & C & E & H \\ \hline J & F & E & D & E & F & J \\ \hline K & J & H & G & H & J & K \\ \hline \end{tabular}$
 Start from the center and label all protruding cells symmetrically. (Note that "I" is left out of this labelling, so there are only 10 labels, not 11, as ending in K would suggest!) More specifically, since there are $4$ given lines of symmetry ($2$ diagonals, $1$ vertical, $1$ horizontal) and they split the plot into $8$ equivalent sections, we can take just one-eighth and study it in particular.
 Each of these sections has $10$ distinct sub-squares, whether partially or in full.
 So since each can be colored either white or black, we choose $2^{10}=1024$ but then subtract the $2$ cases where all are white or all are black. That leaves us with $\boxed{1022}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes symmetric_codes :: nat
assumes h0 : "symmetric_codes = (card {C :: (bool set) ^ (nat * nat). \<exists> f. bij f \<and> (\<forall> i j. i < 7 \<and> j < 7 \<longrightarrow> 
((f (i, j) = f (j, i)) \<and> (f (i, j) = f (6 - i, j)) \<and> (f (i, j) = f (i, 6 - j)) \<and> (f (i, j) = f (6 - i, 6 - j))
\<and> (f (i, j) = f (6 - j, i)) \<and> (f (i, j) = f (j, 6 - i)) \<and> (f (i, j) = f (6 - j, 6 - i)))})}"
shows  "symmetric_codes = 1022"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem:
How many symmetric codes are there on a 7x7 grid such that for each pair of coordinates (i, j) with i, j < 7, the code has the following properties:
1. The code at (i, j) is the same as the code at (j, i).
2. The code at (i, j) is the same as the code at (6 - i, j).
3. The code at (i, j) is the same as the code at (i, 6 - j).
4. The code at (i, j) is the same as the code at (6 - i, 6 - j).
5. The code at (i, j) is the same as the code at (6 - j, i).
6. The code at (i, j) is the same as the code at (j, 6 - i).
7. The code at (i, j) is the same as the code at (6 - j, 6 - i).

The total number of such symmetric codes is 1022.

a_6.formal problem:

fixes symmetric_scanning_codes :: nat
assumes h0 : "symmetric_scanning_codes = (\<Sum> i = 1..49. i choose 1)"
and h1 : "symmetric_scanning_codes = 1022"
shows  "symmetric_scanning_codes = 1022"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A scanning code consists of a $7 \times 7$ grid of squares, with some of its squares colored black and the rest colored white. There must be at least one square of each color in this grid of $49$ squares. A scanning code is called $\textit{symmetric}$ if its look does not change when the entire square is rotated by a multiple of $90 ^{\circ}$ counterclockwise around its center, nor when it is reflected across a line joining opposite corners or a line joining midpoints of opposite sides. $\textbf{(A)} \text{ 510} \qquad \textbf{(B)} \text{ 1022} \qquad \textbf{(C)} \text{ 8190} \qquad \textbf{(D)} \text{ 8192} \qquad \textbf{(E)} \text{ 65,534}$
 The final Answer is 1022

 Draw a $7 \times 7$ square. $\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline K & J & H & G & H & J & K \\ \hline J & F & E & D & E & F & J \\ \hline H & E & C & B & C & E & H \\ \hline G & D & B & A & B & D & G \\ \hline H & E & C & B & C & E & H \\ \hline J & F & E & D & E & F & J \\ \hline K & J & H & G & H & J & K \\ \hline \end{tabular}$
 Start from the center and label all protruding cells symmetrically. (Note that "I" is left out of this labelling, so there are only 10 labels, not 11, as ending in K would suggest!) More specifically, since there are $4$ given lines of symmetry ($2$ diagonals, $1$ vertical, $1$ horizontal) and they split the plot into $8$ equivalent sections, we can take just one-eighth and study it in particular.
 Each of these sections has $10$ distinct sub-squares, whether partially or in full.
 So since each can be colored either white or black, we choose $2^{10}=1024$ but then subtract the $2$ cases where all are white or all are black. That leaves us with $\boxed{1022}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes symmetric_scanning_codes :: nat
assumes h0 : "symmetric_scanning_codes = (\<Sum> i = 1..49. i choose 1)"
and h1 : "symmetric_scanning_codes = 1022"
shows  "symmetric_scanning_codes = 1022"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the total number of symmetric scanning codes that can be formed by choosing 1 element from each of the first 49 sets. The final answer is 1022.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes symmetric_scanning_codes :: nat
assumes h0 : "symmetric_scanning_codes = (\<Sum> k \<in> {1, 2, 4}. 2 powr (k * 7 div 4) - 2)"
shows  "symmetric_scanning_codes = 1022"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

More specifically, since there are $4$ given lines of symmetry ($2$ diagonals, $1$ vertical, $1$ horizontal) and they split the plot into $8$ equivalent sections, we can take just one-eighth and study it in particular.
 Each of these sections has $10$ distinct sub-squares, whether partially or in full.
 So since each can be colored either white or black, we choose $2^{10}=1024$ but then subtract the $2$ cases where all are white or all are black. That leaves us with $\boxed{1022}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes symmetric_scanning_codes :: nat
assumes h0 : "symmetric_scanning_codes = (\<Sum> k \<in> {1, 2, 4}. 2 powr (k * 7 div 4) - 2)"
shows  "symmetric_scanning_codes = 1022"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the sum of the symmetric scanning codes, which is defined as the sum of $2^{(k * 7) / 4} - 2$ for $k$ in the set $\{1, 2, 4\}$. The final answer is $1022$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem symmetric_scanning_codes:
  fixes N :: nat
  assumes h0 : "N = number_of_symmetric_scanning_codes"
shows  "N = 1022"

(* ### Problem

There must be at least one square of each color in this grid of $49$ squares. More specifically, since there are $4$ given lines of symmetry ($2$ diagonals, $1$ vertical, $1$ horizontal) and they split the plot into $8$ equivalent sections, we can take just one-eighth and study it in particular.
 Each of these sections has $10$ distinct sub-squares, whether partially or in full.
 So since each can be colored either white or black, we choose $2^{10}=1024$ but then subtract the $2$ cases where all are white or all are black. That leaves us with $\boxed{1022}$.
 *)

theorem symmetric_scanning_codes:
  fixes N :: nat
  assumes h0 : "N = number_of_symmetric_scanning_codes"
shows  "N = 1022"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the number of symmetric scanning codes. The total number of symmetric scanning codes is 1022.
